column4: Your first step would be to check if you can ping the remote machine.
:i can
: what's the next step?
Using Nautilus > GoTo > Location > Network, can you see an entry 'Windows network'?
:i can
: but when i click on it nothing appears
Double-click on Windows network should display the shares available to you. If not I presume that your smb.conf file is wrong.
: where is the proper smb.conf file?
/usr/share/samba/smb.conf
: i tried replacing the etc/samba/smb.conf with /usr/share/samba/smb.conf but still it doesnt show up
I made a mistake. The file /etc/samba/smb.conf is your personal Samba configuration file. Its contents should resemble that of your friend's mutatis mutandis.
:it is mutatis mutandis .infact i replaced it also!!!
But still after rebooting Nautilus cannot see your friend's share?
:and the worst thing is he doesnt have samba running when checked in adminstration->services and i have both samba and nfs running!!!!
NFS does not matter. You either try Samba or NFS. Please do not mix them (at least not at the beginning.)
there is a lan and many comps are sharing
both windows and linux
are shared
If he doesn't have a samba client running then he will never receive a remote file.
: its not showing in ps -aef
May be you are referring to a Samba server. A Samba server may be located anywhere in a LAN, it has not to be at your firend's location.
What is not shown in ps -aef?
: SAMBA
Then you better install and launch your Samba client.
